newsitem.title: USA: W. Virginia to vote on stock market investments.
newsitem.headline: W. Virginia to vote on stock market investments.

text.p: The West Virginia Legislature has approved a proposal allowing voters to decide whether state pension money can be invested in the stock market, a Senate clerk said Monday.
The proposed constitutional amendment will go before voters in a special election Sept 27.

The ballot asks voters "to authorize the investment of state or public funds in common stocks or other equity investments and to further require the Legislature to establish guidelines and procedures for the prudent investment of such funds."

Lawmakers created a private West Virgina Trust Fund last year to invest the $4 billion pension and workers' compensation funds in stocks and other investments. But the state Supreme Court ruled that the move violated a state constitutional prohibition against putting public money in stocks.
The court said the authorization could only be given via constitutional amendment.
West Virginia is the only state that still prohibits equity investment of public money, a hold-over from the stock market crash that preceded the Great Depression.

In addition to authorizing the referendum, the proposal approved late Saturday creates a 13-member West Virginia Management Board that combines the duties now performed by the Trust Fund Board and the state Board of Investments.
The state treasurer will perform non-investment functions that currently are the responsiblity of the investment board.
